sec.title: BRAF Inhibitors Activate MEK and ERK in RAS Mutant Melanoma Cells
sec.p: We selected four drugs for our studies. Sorafenib is a class II (inactive conformation binder) drug that inhibits V600EBRAF at 40 nM, CRAF at 13 nM, and several other kinases in the low nM range. It is the least-selective drug that we used. PLX4720 is a class I (active conformation binder) inhibitor that is highly selective and inhibits V600EBRAF at 13 nM. 885-A is a close analog of the class I inhibitor SB590885 that is also highly selective for BRAF. It inhibits V600EBRAF at 2 nM, is ineffective against a panel of 64 other protein kinases, and preferentially blocks BRAF mutant cancer cell proliferation. Finally, we also used the potent and selective MEK inhibitor PD184352.

As expected, all four drugs blocked ERK activity in BRAF mutant A375 melanoma cells. Similarly, all four drugs inhibited ERK in SkMel24, SkMel28, D25, and WM266.4 cells, another four lines that express mutant BRAF. We also tested the drugs in D04, MM415, MM485, and WM852 NRAS mutant cells. As expected, PD184352 and sorafenib inhibited ERK in all of these lines. Surprisingly, however, PLX4720 and 885-A caused an unexpected increase in ERK activity in the NRAS mutant cells. NRAS or CRAF depletion by RNA interference (RNAi) blocked MEK/ERK activation by PLX4720 and 885-A in NRAS mutant cells and we show that 885-A activated CRAF in these cells. We previously reported that oncogenic RAS requires CRAF but not BRAF to activate MEK and consistent with this, BRAF is inactive in NRAS mutant cells. These data therefore present an intriguing paradox. BRAF is not active and is not required for MEK/ERK activation in RAS mutant cells. Nevertheless, BRAF inhibitors hyperactivate CRAF and MEK in these cells, so we studied the underlying mechanism(s).
